answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I have found some links that may help answer your question.
The link below goes to a report completed by the Texas Comptroller’s office on their new four days a week 40 hour work week schedule. The results address topics like program implementation, employee retention, employee productivity, and cutting costs of facility utilities.
http://www.window.state.tx.us/specialrpt/altschedule/Alternative_Wrk_Sched.pdf
I also found a study done by Utah State University evaluating different alternate work week patterns for their human resources department.
http://www.usu.edu/pea/files/uploads/AlternativeWorkSched.pdf
Something a little different I found that might also be useful is a report done by the University of Tennessee evaluating alternative work weeks for police departments.
http://www.mtas.tennessee.edu/Knowledgebase.nsf/0/6E608ACA119A3DE0852575F9004B7BAF/$FILE/Compressed%20Work%20Schedules.pdf
Additionally, I included the article below which is a good resource for general information about alternate work week schedules. It is an essay from MIT written for employers considering flexible work arrangements.
http://hrweb.mit.edu/system/files/all/worklife/flexible_work_arrangements.pdf
I hope these help!
Ali Iannolo
ICMA Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

author: Pamela Muse
text:
The City of Gilbert, AZ would appreciate receiving copies of your performance measurement results from implementing a compressed workweek/alternative work schedule.  
With our newly implemented compressed workshop, we plan to measure such things as cost savings, employee morale, customer satisfaction and productivity.

Kurt Sharp, M.P.A.
